intro: Aframomum chlamydanthum, commonly known as the African ginger or wild ginger, is a member of the Zingiberaceae family. It is a perennial herb characterized by its tall, erect stem and broad, lance-shaped leaves. The plant produces small, fragrant flowers that are typically white or pale yellow, arranged in a spike. Its rhizomes, which are underground stems, are often used in traditional medicine and as a spice. The botanical features of Aframomum chlamydanthum make it a valuable species in both ecological and medicinal contexts.
